name: OWASP Aarhus Chapter Meeting - August
description:
OWASP Aarhus and EAAA are hosting the next meetup on August 24th, 18:30 – 21:30 where we will be doing lighting talks.

The agenda is therefore still open and feel free to reach out, if you would like to make a short presentation (approx. 20 minutes). It does not have to be a technical presentation, we are open to and welcome presentations about war stories, personal stories, experiences or just cool stuff.

EAAA will provide snacks and drinks!

name: Reversing Stories – Primitives in The Pocket
description:
In the world of vulnerability research & exploit development, much of the public research and findings are primarily centered around the result of said research and activities. However, a lesser known and even lesser publicly talked about part of research is what happens when a bug is discovered where at that current time an abusable condition is not clearly present. What happens? Is this bug now worthless or not worth inspecting further? Many professional teams have a multitude of bugs to analyze specifically from fuzzing campaigns. This can cause teams to have to prioritize certain types of bugs over others, especially when looking for bugs that can lead to bypassing a specific mitigation. They don’t have time to analyze every single bug in depth majority of the time.  If you are curious about the world of vulnerability research and some of the methodology, this talk aims to help explain a common technique used among research teams where they hold onto potential mitigation breaking bugs in the hopes that in the future an abusable condition become available. We will walk through a real-world example of a bug within the Windows Kernel AFD driver discovered by VerSprite VS-Labs Research team.

Speaker Bio:

Robert Hawes is the active Director of Research at VerSprite VS-Labs Research team. He Enjoys all things in the area of vulnerability research and exploit development. Robert is passionate about discovering zero-day vulnerabilities and developing accompanying exploits for advance capabilities. Robert is currently focused on userland, and kernel driver exploitation centered around the Windows operating system.

name: OWASP Austin Chapter Monthly Meeting - August 2023 (Online)
description:
*Due to supplying lunch for attendees so we have sufficient foods, if you would like to attend in-person at NI. **Please do not pull both an online and in-person ticket as we purchase food for every in-person ticket.***

While the speakers presentation will be online, please feel free to attend in-person at NI. Lunch is sponsored for those who pull tickets via ***https://owasp-austin-2023-august.eventbrite.com***

Online meeting will be opened at 11:30. The chapter presentation will be starting around 11:55 then the Presentation!

Presentation:

***Undercover Agent in Chinese Card Shop Ecosystem: Become a Phishing Master***

Personal Identifiable Information (PII) leaks have become more frequent in recent years, and losses from credit card fraud in 2022 have set records respectively in the USA. Where did this information get leaked and sold in the first place?

The term "Dark web" refers to websites inaccessible without the use of Tor protocol, and given added privacy and anonymity while using Tor, and marketplaces in it are proven to be very attractive to criminals.

An anonymous researcher will share experiences of dealing with vendors from card shops on marketplaces among dark web, focused on insights of shops selling American PIIs, and therefore, TTPs of hackers from these card shops.

name: Dependable dependency systems and supply chain risk
description:
In this talk, Haoxi will be covering the threat landscape of dependency systems (package managers) and why central package registries are not a good model for dependency management. He will then cover open-source tools and data feeds you can use to detect malicious packages in your source code repositories and CICD pipeline, as well as his own open-source experiments in detecting malicious packages in NPM and PyPi.

Event location coming soon.

name: OWASP CUSCO TOUR 2023
description:
El capítulo de OWASP Cusco siguiendo la tradición de realizar reuniones presenciales y virtuales, en esta ocasión presentaremos a grandes oradores relacionados con la seguridad.

En esta ocasión tenemos el agrado de poder contar con el apoyo de la Universidad Andina del Cusco, junto al CIRCLE-UAC.

Este encuentro presencial se realizara el 17 y 18 de Agosto, en el Paraninfo de la Universidad Andina del Cusco ubicado en Larapa, nos permitirá compartir con la comunidad, temas desde análisis web, análisis móvil Android e iOS, análisis de malware, ingeniería reversa, conceptos de criptografía, entre otros muchos temas.

En esta ocasión tenemos el grato placer de contar con las siguientes ponencias:

1. *Factores básicos esenciales de desarrollo seguro*, presentado por Jim Cardenas Cruz

2. *De los CTF a la vida real*, presentado por Everth Gallegos

3. *Bypass root and SSL Pinning* presentado por Rafael Limachi Ortiz

4. *Ciberataques Ransomware, Vectores de infección* presentado por César Farro

5. *Historia de una intrusión física* presentado por Alfredo Mariños Puma

6. *Centro de Operaciones de Seguridad* presentado por Luis Alberto Sota Orellana

7. *Plataformas para iniciar en Ciberseguridad* presentado por Roy Quintana

8. *De cero a system explotando Networker* presentado por Cesar Neira.

Los esperamos....

Happy Hacking!!!

name: Denver OWASP August Meetup - Join Us!
description:
**Everyone is welcome! Bring a friend...**

Join us August 23 for food, drinks, networking and an exciting and timely presentation on "API Security: A CISO Perspective" from one of the best and brightest in the industry: Gina Yacone. Networking with your peers starts at 5 - food is served at 5:30 and the presentation starts at 6.

**Sponsor: A big thank you to our Denver OWASP sponsor**

**Presentation Title:** API Security: A CISO Perspective

**Presentation Details:** Enterprises manage thousands of Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). Many APIs are not routed through a proxy such as an API Gateway or Web Application Firewall (API);

therefore, those APIs are not monitored, audited, and may be vulnerable to mistakes or bad actors. Enterprise security teams are playing catch-up when it comes to API security. How are CISOs and security leadership developing governance round API security and incident response readiness?

In this talk, we will discuss:

1.What are APIs?

2.Why Should API security be top of mind to leadership?

3.API breaches making headlines.

4.API challenges

5.API Breach Examples

6.Approaches to API security

Key takeaways:

1\. APIs are Everywhere

2\. How are APIs tied to business success?

3\. Why having an API strategy is important?

4\. How to develop API lifecycle management?

name: OWASP Italy Day 2023
description:
In collaboration with Politecnico di Milano (Polimi) University, we are excited to announce the upcoming OWASP Italy Day 2023 on September 11th. It will be a full-day event dedicated to application security (AppSec)!

The Open Worldwide Application Security Project (OWASP) stands as a well known international non-profit organization dedicated to the crucial field of web and application security.

At its core, OWASP operates as a vibrant online community, diligently producing a wealth of freely-available resources. These include insightful articles, comprehensive methodologies, extensive documentation, cutting-edge tools, and advanced technologies, all focused on bolstering web application security.

The impact of OWASP's work extends far and wide, with numerous standards, books, tools, and organizations drawing upon the invaluable insights provided by the Top OWASP 10 project. Esteemed entities such as MITRE, PCI DSS, the Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA-STIG), and the United States Federal Trade Commission (FTC) all recognize and reference OWASP's contributions.

An eagerly anticipated event in the OWASP calendar is the OWASP Italy Day 2023. This captivating one-day conference is exclusively dedicated to web application and software security, as well as application security testing tools and technologies.

It presents a golden opportunity for attendees to expand their knowledge on critical application security topics and to network with esteemed professionals and experts. Participants include application security professionals/managers, software engineers, software quality engineers/testers, and computer science students.

For further details regarding the OWASP Italy Day 2023, please refer to the following link:

[https://owasp.org/www-chapter-italy/events/OWASPItalyDay2023](https://owasp.org/www-chapter-italy/events/OWASPItalyDay2023)

name: OWASP Community Day
description:
**OWASP Community Day Lahore**

Join us for the highly anticipated OWASP (Open Web Application Security Project) Community Day in Lahore! This event is a gathering of cybersecurity enthusiasts, professionals, students, and experts who are passionate about web application security and its importance in today's digital landscape.

During this day-long event, you will have the opportunity to engage with like-minded individuals, learn from industry leaders, and expand your knowledge in the field of web application security. The OWASP Community Day Lahore aims to promote collaboration, knowledge sharing, and awareness of the latest trends and best practices in securing web applications.

_**Highlights of the OWASP Community Day Lahore:_**

1. Expert Talks: Listen to renowned cybersecurity experts and thought leaders as they share their insights and experiences in web application security. Gain valuable knowledge about emerging threats, vulnerabilities, and effective countermeasures.

2. Hands-on Workshops: Participate in interactive workshops conducted by industry professionals where you can enhance your practical skills in areas such as secure coding, penetration testing, threat modeling, and secure software development.

3. Networking Opportunities: Connect with fellow cybersecurity enthusiasts, professionals, and students in a collaborative and engaging environment. Expand your professional network, share ideas, and forge valuable connections with individuals who share your passion for web application security.

4. Capture The Flag (CTF) Challenges: Test your skills and compete in exciting Capture The Flag challenges designed to simulate real-world scenarios. Solve security puzzles, find vulnerabilities, and demonstrate your expertise to win attractive prizes.

5. Lightning Talks and Demos: Engage in quick-paced lightning talks and live demonstrations, where participants showcase innovative tools, techniques, and research findings related to web application security. Discover new solutions and gain inspiration from cutting-edge projects.

6. Community Projects and Initiatives: Learn about ongoing OWASP projects and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to the community. Explore opportunities to collaborate on open-source security tools, research papers, and resources that benefit the broader cybersecurity ecosystem.

Don't miss out on this incredible opportunity to be part of the OWASP Community Day Lahore! Mark your calendars and join us for a day filled with knowledge sharing, skill-building, and networking in the vibrant world of web application security. Together, let's make the web a safer place for everyone.

**Note: Please stay tuned for updates on speakers, workshops, and additional event details on our official website and social media channels.**

We look forward to welcoming you to the OWASP Community Day Lahore!

name: Hands-on API Security Workshop with OWASP JuiceShop
description:
Step into the world of API Security in an immersive two-hour hands-on training event offered by [Akto](https://akto.io) and in collaboration by OWASP LA!

We’re excited to announce this opportunity for appsec teams to enhance their skills in API Security and writing business logic tests. This instructor led hands-on workshop focuses on creating and running business logic tests using Akto. You will learn to write ten different business logic tests, which will then be executed against Juice Shop and other vulnerable apps. The goal of the workshop is to give hands-on experience in writing and automating custom API security tests related to authentication, authorization and access control issues. The workshop aims to be interactive, engaging, and an enriching learning experience. You will learn the fundamentals of writing, automating, and executing business logic tests. By the end of this training, participants will be able to automate 10 business logic tests, a key skill in the realm of API security.

What to Expect?

* By the end of the workshop participants will be able to write 10 business logic tests focused on authentication, authorization and access control issues.

* Networking opportunity with fellow security professionals.

* Ask absolutely any questions about securing APIs

Requirements:

* Attendees are required to bring their laptops

Participants are encouraged to bring their own API projects or sample APIs they are trying to test to receive personalized guidance and recommendations during the workshop. We will help everyone write their own custom tests during the workshop itself so you can test your own APIs. If not, we will be using Juice Shop or other vulnerable apps for demo purposes.

**Food and drinks** will be provided and there's a free 90 minute **parking** available across the street.

name: OWASP LA Monthly In-Person Meeting - AUG 23, 2023
description:
**TOPIC**: AppSec 2.0: Reimagine AppSec With Runtime Analysis

Join us for great networking, dinner and drinks, and see a presentation by Kiran Kamity, CEO and Founder of Deepfactor.

**ABSTRACT**: SCA tools (container and dependency scans) generate too much noise. Runtime security tools don’t understand SCA findings, and don’t come in until production. What if you could marry SCA with runtime analysis during dev, test, and prod?

In this session, we will discuss how the next generation of AppSec needs to go beyond just integrating static SCA into your CI pipeline, to analyzing insecure behaviors inside running apps and correlating that back to SCA to understand which vulnerable components are actually loaded into memory and used by your application. This new approach to AppSec will detect both known vulnerabilities/CVEs with SCA scans and unknown vulnerabilities with runtime analysis. It will then prioritize known vulnerabilities with runtime correlation of SCA findings. End result: you catch most of the key risks in your app, prioritize the key items your devs need to work on without flooding them with alerts, and remove unused components from your containers to burn down your CVE debt rapidly….and achieve the true mission of AppSec…to empower engineering and security teams to create secure applications."

**Thanks to our Sponsor**: *[Deepfactor](https://www.deepfactor.io/)*

*Deepfactor Developer Security is a new approach to AppSec that is cloud-native and developer-friendly. It helps enterprises address supply chain and DevSecOps initiatives with a unique technology approach that combines SCA (Software Composition Analysis), SBOM (Software Bill of Materials) and Runtime Security.*

**SPONSORSHIP Opportunities Available**

*Vendors interested in sponsoring please send an email to sponsorship.la@owasp.org*

**CODE OF CONDUCT**

We hope you enjoy the event, we care deeply about inclusivity and diversity so that OWASP is a comfortable and welcoming community for everyone. Please reach out to one of our chapter leaders if you have any feedback/concerns or would like to speak to us, we take these matters very seriously. You can find out more about our policies here:

[https://owasp.org/www-policy/operational/conferences-events.html#conference-and-event-anti-harassment-policy](https://owasp.org/www-policy/operational/conferences-events.html#conference-and-event-anti-harassment-policy)

name: Reducing Alert Fatigue with Container Scans
description:
**NOTE: IN-PERSON EVENT**

**Speaker:** Kiran Kamity, Founder & CEO, Deepfactor

**Topic:** Reducing Alert Fatigue with Container Scans: Correlate, Prioritize and Filter Based on Usage

**Abstract:**

Scenario: Your application is composed of 12 docker containers. Together they have 400 packages. When you run a container scan with an SCA (Software Composition Analysis) tool, you notice that 120 of them have vulnerabilities. Your security team is asking you to fix all the critical and high vulnerabilities, but your dev/DevOps team doesn’t have the cycles. What do you do?

Today, developers and DevOps engineers are being asked to address vulnerabilities and supply chain risks in container images. However, the volume of noisy security alerts often leads to developers ignoring them entirely or wasting valuable sprint time researching “false positives.” This session will focus on how security and engineering teams can correlate vulnerabilities with runtime information, prioritize alerts based on usage, and filter out false positives that don’t represent a true exposure of a vulnerability. Understanding runtime information can provide intelligence such as applicability of the CVE to the running environment, reachability, and usage. This session will focus on usage. Prioritizing security updates to only used packages in your container image is a highly effective approach to reducing alert fatigue with your container scans. In addition, your DevOps team can even consider removing some of the unused packages and shrink your container images.

As an example, the session will include a demonstration of a typical SCA static container scan of a sample open-source test application and then show how an engineering team can filter alerts to reduce the number of vulnerable and used alerts that actually need to be fixed by developers by up to 90%.

**Bio:**

Kiran Kamity is the Founder & CEO of Deepfactor. He is a serial Silicon Valley entrepreneur with a passion for building products that meet a need and make a business impact—with Deepfactor that’s empowering engineering teams to create secure cloud native applications. Prior to Deepfactor, Kiran was the Head of Product at Cisco Cloud BU, Founder/CEO at ContainerX (acquired by Cisco), and the Founder/VP at RingCube (acquired by Citrix). Kiran is a TEDx speaker and loves nature, travel, and food.

**Schedule:**

6:00pm - 6:40pm Networking, Food & Drink

6:40pm - 7:40pm Presentation

7:40pm - 8:00pm Networking

### **Code of Conduct**

We hope you enjoy the event, we care deeply about inclusivity and diversity so that OWASP is a comfortable and welcoming community for everyone. Please reach out to one of our chapter leaders if you have any feedback/concerns or would like to speak to us, we take these matters very seriously. You can find out more about our policies here:

[https://owasp.org/www-policy/operational/conferences-events.html#conference-and-event-anti-harassment-policy](https://owasp.org/www-policy/operational/conferences-events.html#conference-and-event-anti-harassment-policy)

### **Sponsorship**

Vendors who are interested in sponsoring OWASP OC monthly meetings, please send an email to [orange-county-leaders@owasp.org](http://orange-county-leaders@owasp.org)

name: OWASP x Okta |  IoTSecurity101 - Art of exploiting real world devices
description:
\*\*\* THIS TALK IS BOTH ONLINE (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8LN35082u-4) and OFFLINE @ the Okta offices \*\*\*

**TALK**

**IoTSecurity101 - Art of exploiting real world devices**

**Summary:**

Delve deep into the realm of Internet of Things (IoT) security in this session, where we unmask the common attack vectors threatening our connected devices. A key highlight will be a walkthrough of ARM assembly exploit development, providing the attendees with practical resources to fortify their knowledge in this area. The grand finale will be an interactive demonstration where we will exploit three existing vulnerabilities in the IoTGoat project. This talk is not only about uncovering vulnerabilities but also about empowering you with the mindset to build a more secure IoT ecosystem.

**Presenter:**

Chirag (@cjhackerz) is currently an Application Security Analyst at MindGeek Canada, where he brings a rich blend of AppSec experience to the table. Before relocating to Canada, Chirag was deeply involved in conducting critical infrastructure and end consumer product penetration testing engagements. Who also delivered numerous talks at OWASP chapters across India. Beyond the podium, Chirag is passionate about knowledge sharing. This drive is reflected in his blog, [https://cjhackerz.net](https://cjhackerz.net/), where he has provided insights drawn from his diverse and extensive experience in the field. His seasoned perspective and commitment to fostering an informed cybersecurity community make him a valued figure in the realm of application security.
